awd_titl_txt: INFEWS: US-China-Quantifying complex adaptive FEW systems with a coupled agent-based modeling framework
awd_abstract_narration:
With growing populations and economic development, the challenges of water, energy, and food security, as well as their inter-relations, have risen to the forefront as global concerns. When the scale of the problem is reduced to a regional level like a large river basin, nuances across these challenges emerge. This is because the basin-scale food, energy, and water (FEW) systems are essentially a coupled natural-human complex system of systems and should be collectively denoted as FEW nexus. Within the nexus both natural processes (e.g., rainfall-runoff for water supply) and human behavior (e.g., energy and food commodity markets and policies) are interdependent at hierarchical spatiotemporal scales. There are significant knowledge and capability gaps associated with this FEW nexus, particularly in the context of data and modeling. This project addresses these gaps by developing a new mathematical modeling framework to decipher the complex, adaptive food-energy-water system of systems (FEWSoS). This modeling tool can ensure policy coherence and coordination among stakeholders to build synergies and generate co-benefits (e.g., improving security in water, energy and food sectors simultaneously) that enable us to address the future challenges across multiple sectors. The project will leverage Mountaintop Initiative at Lehigh University for educational outreach by allowing engagement of small groups of interdisciplinary projects. They will also engage undergraduate students in the ADVANCE program and the BALANCE program in the STEM disciplines. They will also engage an international student from Ethiopia as a part of this project. Finally, the project will have a kickoff and wrap-up meeting between the US and China investigators.
 
The proposed modeling framework will be centering on an agent-based representation of the linkages among food, energy and water sub-systems and between human and physical systems across multiple temporal and spatial scales. The three main research objectives are: (1) Constructing a comprehensive knowledge platform with a set of quantitative metrics for sustainability, vulnerability, and resilience of a FEWSoS via inventory and evaluation of both public and local data and information from the food, energy and water sectors; (2) Developing a spatially and temporally distributed modeling framework that analyzes the food-energy-water interactions in a given FEWSoS from local to river-basin scales. The interactions among food, energy, and water will be quantified with the aid of a hydro-agro-economic model (food module), an energy production cost model (energy module) and a process-based hydrologic model (water module); (3) Testing the utility of the developed FEWSoS modeling framework over two international river basins in the U.S. and China: the Columbia River and the Mekong River to elucidate similarities and differences in these FEWSoS, hence generating new understanding that is transferable to other river basins. PIs diverse backgrounds and experiences in water resources management, hydrologic modeling, energy market modeling, and hydro-agro-economic modeling from both the U.S. and China teams provide an excellent opportunity for graduate students and postdocs to work together across disciplines. The kick-off meeting in the US and the wrap-up meeting in China will allow all PIs to engage stakeholders from the beginning till the end of the project and make sure the model development echoes real world needs.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project deciphers the complex and adaptive interactions of the basin-scale food, energy, and water (FEW) systems that are collectively denoted as FEW Nexus. To achieve this goal, we developed new mathematical modeling frameworks that consider interdependent natural processes (e.g., rainfall-runoff for water supply) and human behavior (e.g., energy and food commodity markets and policies) at hierarchical spatiotemporal scales. We worked with both the US and Chinese partners to collect essential data, gather necessary inputs, and verify the modeling structures. We also collaborate with relevant stakeholders throughout the project period to incorporate their feedback on model development and disseminate our results in workshops, conferences, and journal papers. The developed models were used to quantify the effect of climate change on the tradeoff between hydropower development and irrigated water consumption as well as ecosystem health for the future.   

For example, we conducted a meta-analysis of previous FEW Nexus modeling literature and identified additional sectors that should be included such as ecosystems, soil health, human health, and waste management. We also used a workshop and a regional survey to collect stakeholders' opinions about FEW Nexus in our main study area the Columbia River Basin between the US and Canada. We found that people understand a strong relationship between water and energy sustainability and interagency coordination mechanisms is critical to successful policy implementation. These studies provide the necessary background for our models and concepts development. For example, we developed models that quantify the bidirectional interactions between human behavior (e.g., irrigation) and natural system (e.g., streamflow) with a rule-based stochastic simulation approach and a machine learning-based approach. We applied an energy market model from our partner to evaluate the effect of dam removal on the ecosystem. We also developed a conceptual framework to evaluate catchment water balance and vegetation dynamics at different spatial scales. We improved our water module by explicitly representing hydropower reservoirs and evaluating their impacts on reservoir storage variations and downstream rivers.

Then, these developed models and concepts were used to assess the impact of climate change on various FEW Nexus. For example, we expanded the abovementioned dam removal study and concluded that when we included climate metrics, such as fossil fuel dispatch, and carbon tax strategy in the evaluation, the dam removal decisions that are favorable for ecosystem services will be different. The model that considers bidirectional interactions between human and natural systems has been applied in several river basins globally. For example, we quantified the effect of dam development and climate change on the ecosystem in the Mekong River with our Chinese collaborators and identified "high-risk" regions in the basin. We investigated how human adaptation uncertainties might impact water scarcity in the Colorado River and the results suggested that human influence will accumulate, not offset, from a smaller spatial scale to the river basin scale. We highlight the tradeoff between irrigated water consumption with hydropower generation and the ecosystem flow regime under climate change in the Columbia River. The results identified the "tipping points" in temperature and precipitation change that might intensify the tradeoff relationship in food, energy, water, and ecosystem sectors.  

In sum, the outcomes of this project advance our understanding of studying and predicting the influence of climate change and different socioeconomic dynamics on the interactions of food, energy, water, and ecosystem. We have disseminated these results in different academic conferences and journal papers in the past four years. But, most importantly, we also had direct interactions with people outside of academia. We hosted a stakeholder engagement workshop in the Northwest US and invited federal, state, and local officials as well as tribal representatives and national lab scientists to help us frame the scope of our models? development. Our Chinese partners host an international symposium at Wuhan that covered a wide variety of cutting-edge topics related to hydrological sciences and water resources management. Several international experts on FEW Nexus were invited and the entire US team of this project was also there to present our results. This project has supported three Ph.D. students at George Washington University, four Ph.D. students at the University of Houston, two Ph.D. students, and one postdoctoral scientist at Lehigh University. Ph.D. students who graduated with the support of this project are all continuing their professional careers in a similar "FEW Nexus" path in other universities (e.g., Virginia Polytechnic Institute and State University and Purdue University), national labs (e.g., Pacific Northwest National Laboratory) or regional organizations (e.g., Northwest Power and Conservation Council).
